[[Hengest]] & [[Horsa]] (half-brothers) | spouse= | children= | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Heorrenda''' was a son of a [[Men|Man]] [[Eriol]] and an [[Elf]] [[Naimi]],In one of the texts associated with ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'', Heorrenda's mother is named [[Nelmir]], and he also has a brother called [[Hendwine]].{{PE|15}}, "[[Names and Required Alterations]]", Appendix, ''Text X'', p. 17 according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''10''', p. 290 == History == Heorrenda was born in Tol Eressëa, and, according to one text, it was he who completed the ''[[Golden Book]]'', in which were written the histories of the [[Elves]], that was kept in Tol Eressëa.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''11''', p. 290 After the [[Faring Forth]],According to another text, Heorrenda accompanied his father Eriol in his return from Tol Eressëa to the [[Great Lands]]. In that text, it was Eriol himself who hastened the Faring Forth, and thus ultimately doomed it.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''14''', p. 294 the disastrous attempt by the [[Elves]] of Tol Eressëa to save their [[Ilkorindi|kin]] in the Great Lands which resulted in their total defeat and eventual fading, evil Men invaded Tol Eressëa, now anchored near the coast of the Great Lands. Afterwards however, Heorrenda, alongside his half-brothers [[Hengest]] and [[Horsa]], led what would become the [[wikipedia:English people|English]] people and conquered Tol Eressëa, after which it became known as [[wikipedia:England|England]].{{LT2|VI}}, p. 293 There, he would settle in what was once the village of [[Tavrobel]], now called ''Gréata Hægwudu'', and which would eventually become known as the village of [[wikipedia:Great Haywood|Great Haywood]].{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''13''', pp. 291-2 He, his half-brothers, and the English people as a whole, would ultimately be the only group of [[Men]] to remain friendly to the Elves, and to keep the "true tradition of the [[Elves|fairies]]". == Etymology == The name ''Heorrenda'' is in [[Old English]] and of uncertain meaning. It is found in old Germanic poetry (such as the Old English poem ''[[Déor (poem)|Déor]]'') and the first element has been interpreted as ''heorra'' meaning "a hinge, cardinal point"; an etymological connection with the Latin ''corvus'' and Greek ''korax'' (both meaning "raven") has been proposed, possibly in the sense of a pick used to play a stringed instrument, with ''Heorrenda'' meaning "minstrel". == Other names == Heorrenda was also known as '''''Heruven''''' in [[Qenya]], with '''''Herwent''''' being its [[Gnomish]] equivalent. These two names were most likely phonological imitations of the name ''Heorrenda'' instead of being translations of its meaning. The first element of ''Heruven'' is probably ''[[heru]]'' ("lord"), while the second element of ''Herwent'' is most likely ''[[gwent]]/gwenn/gwen'' ("large, big; fine") - hence ''Heruven'' and ''Herwent'' might mean "great lord". == Genealogy == {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | | | WOD | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |WOD=[[wikipedia:Odin|Wóden]]}} {{familytree | | | |:| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |}} {{familytree | | | |:| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |}} {{familytree | | | HED | | | | | | | | | | | | | | TUL | | | | VAL |HED=[[Heden]]|TUL=[[Tulkastor]]|VAL=[[Valwë]]}} {{familytree | |,|-|^|-|.| | | | | | | | | | | |,|-|^|-|.| | | |!| |}} {{familytree | BEO | | EOH | | | | | | | | | | SIB | | VAI |~| LIN |BEO=[[Beorn (son of Heden)|Beorn]]

[[wikipedia:5th century|5th century]]''}} {{familytree/end}} * The name of Hendwine's mother is not Naimi but ''[[Nelmir]]'' in the text on which the basis of his inclusion is founded upon - neither is her relation to Lindo and Vairë elaborated on. == Other versions of the legendarium == In some of the later notes, '''Heorrenda''', called "the harper", is described as being the son of [[Ælfwine]] and [[Earissë]], the daughter of [[Lindo]]. Here he has a brother called [[Hlúdwine]].{{PE|15}}, "[[Names and Required Alterations]]", Appendix, ''Text XI'', p. 18 === Later etymology === In these texts, the Qenya name for ''Heorrenda'' is '''''Heruvendo''''' ('''''Horwin''''' being its Gnomish equivalent). As with the earlier names ([[Heorrenda#Etymology|see above]]) ''Heruvendo'' likewise seems to be a phonological imitation of ''Heorrenda'', corresponding even more closely than ''Heruven''.{{PE|15}}, "[[Names and Required Alterations]]", Appendix, ''Text XII'', p. 18 However, the first element ''Hor-'' in ''Horwin'' cannot be cognate with ''Heru-'' in ''Heruvendo''. It is possible that ''Horwin'' might have been a slip for '''''Herwin''''', though in the old German poem ''[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kudrun Kudrun]'', the form ''Horund'' (or ''Horant'') appears for the name ''Heorrenda'', which might have inspired the Gnomish name of ''Horwin''. === Later genealogy === {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | | | LIN |y| VAI |LIN=[[Lindo]]|VAI=[[Vairë (wife of Lindo)|Vairë]]}} {{familytree | | | | | |!| | | |}} {{familytree | AEL |y| EAR | | |AEL=[[Ælfwine]]|EAR=[[Earissë]]}} {{familytree | |,|-|^|-|.| | | |}} {{familytree | HEO | | HLU | | |HEO='''HEORRENDA'''|HLU=[[Hlúdwine]]}} {{familytree/end}} == Inspiration == The name ''Heorrenda'' appears in the Old English poem ''Déor'', where Heorrenda was a bard that has supplanted Déor, another bard and the main character of the poem, in their lord's favour. In some of [[Tolkien]]'s lectures on the poem ''[[Beowulf (poem)|Beowulf]]'', he named the unknown author of the poem as ''Heorrenda''.{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 323 {{references|notes}} [[Category:Angles]] [[Category:Anglo-Saxons]] [[Category:Characters in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Chroniclers of Arda]] [[Category:Old English names]] [[Category:Rulers in Tol Eressëa]]
